column1: As he started to his feet the second shell struck.
column2: The ceiling cracked open, struts and girders twisted and bent.
column3: The ship shuddered, falling suddenly down, then righting itself as automatic controls took over.
column4: The Captain lay on the floor by the smashed control board.
column5: In the corner Nasha struggled to free herself from the debris.
column6: Outside the men were already sealing the gaping leaks in the side of the ship, through which the precious air was rushing, dissipating into the void beyond.

column12: "So there is life here, after all," he said, half to himself.

column53: Metal doesn't need air to breathe.
column54: Metal doesn't get leukemia from radioactive particles.
column55: Metal doesn't need food and water."
column58: "Anyhow, in the morning I think we should send out a search party.
column59: And meanwhile we should keep on trying to get the ship in condition for the trip back."
column60: "It'll be days before we can take off," Fomar said.
column61: "We should keep every man working here.
column62: We can't afford to send out a party."
column64: "We'll send you in the first party.

column68: "Maybe you can find some of them.
column71: They fired on us once without even knowing who we were or what we came for.
column72: Do you suppose that they fought with each other?
column73: Perhaps they couldn't imagine anyone being friendly, under any circumstances.
column74: What a strange evolutionary trait, inter-species warfare.
column76: "We'll know in the morning," Fomar said.
column78: *       *       *       *       * The sun came up chill and austere.

column87: They walked together, their metal shoes crunching the ground underfoot.

column93: The shock did something to his heart.
column94: He was almost sixty, you know."
column97: I have a great deal of respect for him.
column98: You will be captain in his place, of course.
column100: I prefer to see someone else lead, perhaps you or Fomar.
column101: I've been thinking over the situation and it seems to me that I should declare myself mated to one of you, whichever of you wants to be captain.

column103: "Well, I don't want to be captain.

column106: "I'm rather partial to you," she said.
column107: "We might try it for a time, at least.
column110: They stopped walking, letting Tance catch up.
column111: In front of them was some sort of a ruined building.
column114: This whole place is a natural bowl, a huge valley.
column115: See how the rock formations rise up on all sides, protecting the floor.

column123: But let's go; we don't have much time."
column132: "The white stones, the great broken teeth.

column136: I didn't think we had landed so close."
column138: Tance said, coming up to them.

column149: We don't know what we would be getting into.
column151: They probably have seen us already, for that matter."
column152: "They probably have seen the ship itself," Tance said.
column153: "They probably know right now where they can find it, where they can blow it up.

column156: "If they really want to get us we haven't a chance.

column167: *       *       *       *       * They reached the outskirts of the city at about the middle of the afternoon.
column168: The sun, cold and yellow, hung above them in the colorless sky.
column169: Dorle stopped at the top of a ridge overlooking the city.
column173: The huge concrete piers which they had noticed were not piers at all, but the ruined foundations of buildings.
column174: They had been baked by the searing heat, baked and charred almost to the ground.
column175: Nothing else remained, only this irregular circle of white squares, perhaps four miles in diameter.
column178: A dead skeleton of a city, that's all."
column179: "But it was from here that the firing came," Tance murmured.
column181: "And by someone with a good eye and a great deal of experience," Nasha added.
column183: They walked into the city between the ruined buildings.
column185: They walked in silence, listening to the echo of their footsteps.
column187: "I've seen ruined cities before but they died of old age, old age and fatigue.
column188: This was killed, seared to death.
column189: This city didn't die--it was murdered."
column190: "I wonder what the city was called," Nasha said.
column191: She turned aside, going up the remains of a stairway from one of the foundations.
column192: "Do you think we might find a signpost?
column198: Nasha bent down, touching a concrete stone.
column202: He squatted in the dust, running his gloved fingers over the surface of the stone.
column204: He took a writing stick from the pocket of his pressure suit and copied the inscription on a bit of paper.
column206: The inscription was:     FRANKLIN APARTMENTS "That's this city," Nasha said softly.
column208: Tance put the paper in his pocket and they went on.
column209: After a time Dorle said, "Nasha, you know, I think we're being watched.
column219: "I feel nothing, but perhaps I'm more used to being stared at."
column222: Dorle reached for his hand weapon.
column225: Tance had stopped dead in his tracks, his mouth half open.
column230: Dorle unfastened his hand weapon slowly.
column233: Stark and immense it pointed up at the sky, a mass of steel and glass, set in a huge slab of concrete.
column234: Even as they watched the gun moved on its swivel base, whirring underneath.
column235: A slim vane turned with the wind, a network of rods atop a high pole.
column238: The gun moved again, this time clockwise.
column239: It was mounted so that it could make a full circle.
column240: The barrel lowered a trifle, then resumed its original position.
column250: Nasha came close to him, frowning, looking up at him.
column252: What do you mean, it fires itself?"
column255: Dorle picked up a rock from the ground.
column256: He hesitated a moment and then tossed the rock high in the air.
column257: The rock passed in front of the gun.
column258: Instantly the great barrel moved, the vanes contracted.
column259: *       *       *       *       * The rock fell to the ground.
column260: The gun paused, then resumed its calm swivel, its slow circling.
column261: "You see," Dorle said, "it noticed the rock, as soon as I threw it up in the air.
column262: It's alert to anything that flies or moves above the ground level.
column263: Probably it detected us as soon as we entered the gravitational field of the planet.
column264: It probably had a bead on us from the start.
column266: It knows all about the ship.
column267: It's just waiting for us to take off again."
column268: "I understand about the rock," Nasha said, nodding.
column269: "The gun noticed it, but not us, since we're on the ground, not above.
column270: It's only designed to combat objects in the sky.
column271: The ship is safe until it takes off again, then the end will come."
column277: "A machine that was made to do a job.
column279: How it survived the blast I don't know.
column280: On it goes, waiting for the enemy.
column281: Probably they came by air in some sort of projectiles."
column284: It is hard to believe that they really bombed themselves, fired at themselves."
column286: Except right here, where we're standing.
column287: This one gun, still alert, ready to kill.
column288: It'll go on until it wears out."
column289: "And by that time we'll be dead," Nasha said bitterly.
column290: "There must have been hundreds of guns like this," Dorle murmured.
column291: "They must have been used to the sight, guns, weapons, uniforms.

column304: The barrel swung past them as they stood, rigid and still.

column306: Then the sounds died out and the gun became silent.

column340: "Do you remember the legend that all races have, the myth of the buried treasure, and the dragon, the serpent that watches it, guards it, keeping everyone away?"

column346: *       *       *       *       * Between the three of them they managed to pull up the steel cover and lay it to one side.
column347: Dorle was wet with perspiration when they finished.
column349: He stared into the dark yawning hole.
column351: Nasha clicked on her hand lamp, shining the beam down the stairs.
column352: The steps were thick with dust and rubble.
column353: At the bottom was a steel door.
column356: They watched him reach the door and pull hopefully on it without success.

column369: The bottom of the door glowed red.
column375: In a few minutes they had carried it away in pieces and stacked the pieces on the first step.
column376: Then they went on, flashing the light ahead of them.
column378: Dust lay everywhere, on everything, inches thick.
column379: Wood crates lined the walls, huge boxes and crates, packages and containers.
column380: Tance looked around curiously, his eyes bright.
column384: He picked up a round drum and opened it.
column385: A spool fell to the floor, unwinding a black ribbon.
column386: He examined it, holding it up to the light.
column392: Tance closed the spool up in the drum again.
column397: Dorle was already prying at the wood.
column398: The wood had turned brittle and dry.
column399: He managed to pull a section away.
column401: A boy in a blue garment, smiling pleasantly, staring ahead, young and handsome.
column402: He seemed almost alive, ready to move toward them in the light of the hand lamp.
column403: It was one of them, one of the ruined race, the race that had perished.
column404: For a long time they stared at the picture.

column410: "This is their treasure," Tance said, almost to himself.

column418: Even after their big cities and buildings and industries were destroyed they probably hoped to come back and find this.

column478: *       *       *       *       * It was early the next morning when they reached the ship.
column479: During the night the Captain had died, and the crew had ignited his body, according to custom.
column480: They had stood solemnly around it until the last ember died.
column481: As they were going back to their work the woman and the two men appeared, dirty and tired, still excited.
column482: And presently, from the ship, a line of people came, each carrying something in his hands.
column483: The line marched across the gray slag, the eternal expanse of fused metal.
column484: When they reached the weapon they all fell on the gun at once, with crowbars, hammers, anything that was heavy and hard.
column485: The telescopic sights shattered into bits.
column486: The wiring was pulled out, torn to shreds.
column487: The delicate gears were smashed, dented.
column488: Finally the warheads themselves were carried off and the firing pins removed.
column489: The gun was smashed, the great weapon destroyed.
column490: The people went down into the vault and examined the treasure.
column491: With its metal-armored guardian dead there was no danger any longer.
column492: They studied the pictures, the films, the crates of books, the jeweled crowns, the cups, the statues.
column493: At last, as the sun was dipping into the gray mists that drifted across the planet they came back up the stairs again.
column494: For a moment they stood around the wrecked gun looking at the unmoving outline of it.
column495: Then they started back to the ship.
column496: There was still much work to be done.
column497: The ship had been badly hurt, much had been damaged and lost.
column498: The important thing was to repair it as quickly as possible, to get it into the air.
column499: With all of them working together it took just five more days to make it spaceworthy.
column500: *       *       *       *       * Nasha stood in the control room, watching the planet fall away behind them.
column501: She folded her arms, sitting down on the edge of the table.
column507: "I was thinking that there must have been a time when this planet was quite different, when there was life on it."
column509: It's unfortunate that no ships from our system came this far, but then we had no reason to suspect intelligent life until we saw the fission glow in the sky."
column512: After all, their possessions, their music, books, their pictures, all of that will survive.
column513: We'll take them home and study them, and they'll change us.
column514: We won't be the same afterwards.
column516: Did you see the one of the great winged creature, without a head or arms?
column518: But those wings-- It looked very old.
column519: It will change us a great deal."
column520: "When we come back we won't find the gun waiting for us," Nasha said.
column521: "Next time it won't be there to shoot us down.
column522: We can land and take the treasure, as you call it."
column524: "You'll lead us back there, as a good captain should."
column530: I think, all in all, I really prefer you."
column533: The ship roared up, flying over the ruins of the city.
column534: It turned in a huge arc and then shot off beyond the horizon, heading into outer space.
column535: *       *       *       *       * Down below, in the center of the ruined city, a single half-broken detector vane moved slightly, catching the roar of the ship.
column536: The base of the great gun throbbed painfully, straining to turn.
column537: After a moment a red warning light flashed on down inside its destroyed works.
column538: And a long way off, a hundred miles from the city, another warning light flashed on, far underground.
column541: On the ground above a section of metal slag slipped back.
column543: A moment later a small cart rushed to the surface.
column544: The cart turned toward the city.
column545: A second cart appeared behind it.
column546: It was loaded with wiring cables.
column547: Behind it a third cart came, loaded with telescopic tube sights.
column548: And behind came more carts, some with relays, some with firing controls, some with tools and parts, screws and bolts, pins and nuts.
column549: The final one contained atomic warheads.
column550: The carts lined up behind the first one, the lead cart.
column551: The lead cart started off, across the frozen ground, bumping calmly along, followed by the others.
